[@id:193477]
LinkedIn isn’t as much about connecting and sharing with any of those people as it is about masking the transactional and often cutthroat nature of at-will employment. LinkedIn feeds are a runoff stream of personal branding, full of professional connections posting inspirational quotes, motivational image macros, course completion certificates, life mantras, employee anniversary celebrations, and unintentional corporate cringe galore. It sometimes feels like every post on the world’s top professional networking site is an unintentional meme.

[#Cringe on LinkedIn is Debord’s spectacle at work]

bit.title: Cringe on LinkedIn is Debord’s spectacle at work

bitmark:
[.article:bitmark++]
[@id:193483]
French philosopher, filmmaker, and critic of work, Guy Debord, said that late capitalism has ==**transformed us all into a society of constant spectacle**==|link:https://modernmythology.net/the-society-of-the-spectacle-22175bafc78a|. Mere appearances — our most superficial understanding of things — are changing how we act and react, effectively remaking the world.

bit.body: French philosopher, filmmaker, and critic of work, Guy Debord, said that late capitalism has ==**transformed us all into a society of constant spectacle**==|link:https://modernmythology.net/the-society-of-the-spectacle-22175bafc78a|. Mere appearances — our most superficial understanding of things — are changing how we act and react, effectively remaking the world.

bitmark:

[@id:193484]
But he said that way back in the 1960s, long before the phrase “growing your personal brand.” Now, the phenomenon Debord called the spectacle has metastasized across social networks nearly unrestrained.

Because of its more straightforward transactional nature, the spectacle may be easiest to see on LinkedIn. It’s an iteration of hustle culture — sometimes called burnout culture and grind culture. But it exists in different ways on every social media site. You’ve no doubt seen those Instagram influencer accounts or Tai Lopez YouTube ads with flashy, waxed new Lamborghinis and materialistic signifiers of wealth.

bitmark:
[.article:bitmark--]
[@id:193486]
Posts on LinkedIn are more insufferable and insincere because of how closely the site is tied to work — the key to food, shelter, clothing and the other basic necessities of life. Because many of us find we have little time for life outside the office (and commute to and from), work and life feel synonymous. In fact, many of LinkedIn’s power users have tied their identity to their work, hitching their self-worth entirely to their career.

[#The spectacle of positivity culture]

Obviously, not all of LinkedIn is inspirational quotes, motivational images, and celebrations of success. But the majority of social media posts—whatever the platform — amount to little more than a highly curated set of moments in the otherwise mundane and normal lives of regular people.

[#The spectacle protects the status quo]

bit.title: The spectacle protects the status quo

bitmark:
[.article:bitmark--]
[@id:193508]
The point of the spectacle is to affirm the rightness and naturalness of the status quo. If we say we’re happy, then there’s no need to change anything. Even if any of us find ourselves individually unhappy, we imagine we are the exception. That’s how the spectacle protects the status quo.

bit.body: The point of the spectacle is to affirm the rightness and naturalness of the status quo. If we say we’re happy, then there’s no need to change anything. Even if any of us find ourselves individually unhappy, we imagine we are the exception. That’s how the spectacle protects the status quo.

bitmark:
[.article:bitmark--]
[@id:193509]
The spectacle soothes our discontent, too. It tells us what we want to hear. It whispers, __you can accomplish anything__, or __you’re already happy where you’re at__. As soon as we buy into, carry with us, and repeat the messages of the spectacle, we’re enabling what Debord called “the omnipresent affirmation of the choice already made.”

bit.body: The spectacle soothes our discontent, too. It tells us what we want to hear. It whispers, __you can accomplish anything__, or __you’re already happy where you’re at__. As soon as we buy into, carry with us, and repeat the messages of the spectacle, we’re enabling what Debord called “the omnipresent affirmation of the choice already made.”

[@id:193511]
That’s why our curated LinkedIn feeds — focused on successes, celebrations, brand building, and the glory of the grind — suggest that we’re all already living our best lives in the best possible world. By focusing only on our wins, we reinforce the power of the spectacle and its assertion that nothing needs to change.

And for those already at the top of the pyramid — the wealthy for whom the system works well — change to the status quo is definitely not necessary. Money, power, and all manner of material success are already flowing to them.

[#The social media spectacle causes real mental health issues]

bit.title: The social media spectacle causes real mental health issues

bitmark:
[.article:bitmark--]
[@id:193514]
The image of what a successful life should look like, that spectacle we’re collectively projecting online — the one where we all have it together, we’re excelling at our careers and we’re working hard and playing hard, grinding 24/7 — is bad for us, because it becomes a part of us. We’re measuring our real lives against that fantasy.

bit.body: The image of what a successful life should look like, that spectacle we’re collectively projecting online — the one where we all have it together, we’re excelling at our careers and we’re working hard and playing hard, grinding 24/7 — is bad for us, because it becomes a part of us. We’re measuring our real lives against that fantasy.

bitmark:
[.article:bitmark--]
[@id:193515]
Social media feeds don’t reflect our actual lived experiences. The meticulously curated spectacle seeps like water into every corner of our lives, warping our sense of what is normal and what everyone else is actually doing. It shapes our real lives by changing the norms and expectations we try to live up to. This false impression of the world has incredibly negative effects on mental health and wellbeing.

bit.body: Social media feeds don’t reflect our actual lived experiences. The meticulously curated spectacle seeps like water into every corner of our lives, warping our sense of what is normal and what everyone else is actually doing. It shapes our real lives by changing the norms and expectations we try to live up to. This false impression of the world has incredibly negative effects on mental health and wellbeing.

bitmark:
[.article:bitmark--]
[@id:193516]
Because this funhouse mirror version of normal — in terms of appearance and success — is something most of us will never be able to live up to, we’re left to feel simply not good enough. A ==recent study==|link:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5067824/#:~:text=However%2C%20it%20is%20also%20possible,measure%20up%20to%20others'%20accomplishments.| found that “people who use LinkedIn frequently may also feel increased depression and/or anxiety for a number of reasons, including feeling guilty for the time ‘wasted’ and feeling unable to measure up to others’ accomplishments.”

bit.body: Because this funhouse mirror version of normal — in terms of appearance and success — is something most of us will never be able to live up to, we’re left to feel simply not good enough. A ==recent study==|link:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5067824/#:~:text=However%2C%20it%20is%20also%20possible,measure%20up%20to%20others'%20accomplishments.| found that “people who use LinkedIn frequently may also feel increased depression and/or anxiety for a number of reasons, including feeling guilty for the time ‘wasted’ and feeling unable to measure up to others’ accomplishments.”

[.article:bitmark--]

The spectacle creates a sort of smokescreen because it precludes the knowledge that anyone is unhappy — that anything is less than perfect. The pure fiction of everyone’s career highlight reel only fuels ==the imposter syndrome eight in 10 adults experience==|link:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7174434/|.

At its core, to appear to live a desirable life is really all that’s needed to influence others, to be an influencer. LinkedIn users’ posts about their successes make them objects of desire. When we post online, want to show ourselves as adventurous, well-liked, attractive, and worth following online — in short, desirable.

The tragic logic of LinkedIn — and all social media, really — is that we curate a feed of successes and even reframe our failures as a success to establish an image of a desirable life and career. That desire — which is only possible because we feel we lack something — makes both us and our audience feel forever incomplete.

bit.body: The tragic logic of LinkedIn — and all social media, really — is that we curate a feed of successes and even reframe our failures as a success to establish an image of a desirable life and career. That desire — which is only possible because we feel we lack something — makes both us and our audience feel forever incomplete.

[.article:bitmark--]

We chase after an unattainable version of success we see online to fill some absence in us. And we also want to seem successful and have the adoration of others — what is ultimately the desire of an online audience — another attempt to fill the void. This what makes social media so profitable.

This what makes social media so profitable.
